Description: Lower body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice with handle root; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black, with added red and added white bands; below, part of white feathery lotus bud; exterior: from top, trace of chequer pattern between dilute lines; between roots of handle, large eye filling ornament with red dot in central disk and with black and red triangles on either side; at right of handle root, part of handle frill and guilloche pattern; below, zigzag band between pairs of dilute lines; ancient repair hole; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1888,0601.182 and 1888,0601.466.f. Although Lemos does not discuss this sherd, it ought to belong to her Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1). This newly discovered join (1888,0601.466.f and 1888,0601.182) calls into question the published inscription in Hutton, C. A. 'Inscriptions on pottery from Naukratis', Classical Review 7, 1893, 83, IV because the iconography from this join makes clear that 1888,0601.182 goes to the left of 1924,1201.15.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1576) (phase 2)
